rationale: EORTC 22863 randomized patients with high-risk prostate cancer between those receiving no hormone ablation therapy or 36 months of hormone ablation therapy. EORTC 22961 randomized patients with high-risk prostate cancer between those receiving 6 months or 36 months of hormone ablation therapy. In both studies, the patients who received 36 months of hormone ablation therapy had improved outcomes over the patients with either no hormone ablation therapy or the shorter course of hormone ablation therapy.

question: A 6-year-old child with a normal weight of 40 lb has Hodgkin lymphoma. She has had a 3 lb weight loss over the past 3 months. PET-CT scans showed uptake in the left Cervix and supraclavicular lymph node regions. What Ann Arbor stage is most likely to be associated with these findings?
subject: Pediatrics
rationale: The Ann Arbor staging system incorporates the Cervix and supraclavicular areas as one lymph node region. The mediastinum and axillae are separate regions. B symptoms include 1) unintentional weight loss of >10% of normal body weight over a period of 6 months, 2) drenching night sweats, 3) unexplained night sweats >38 C.

question: Which statement about the treatment of papillary/follicular thyroid cancer is true?
a: EBRT is commonly used to augment 131I ablation.
b: Eating lemon candy immediately after 131I ablation reduces the risk of sialadenitis.
c: Patient mortality is common due to the aggressiveness of these tumors.
d: Older patients have better outcomes than younger patients.
subject: H&N
citations: (1) Beierewaltes WH. The treatment of thyroid cancer with radioactive iodine. Semin Ncul Med. 1978;8:79-94. (2) Blahd W. Nuclear medicine therapy of thyroid cancer. In: Thawley S, Panje W, Batsakis J, et al, eds. Comprehensive management of head and neck tumors. Philadelphia, WB Saunders, 1987. (3) Farahati J, Reiners C, Stuschke M, et al. Differentiated thyroid cancer. Cancer. 1996;77:172-180. (4) Nagada K, Ishibashi T, Takei T, et al. Does lemon candy decrease salivary gland damage after radioiodine therapy for thyroid cancer? J Nucl Med. 2005;46:261-266.
rationale: The staging system for papillary/follicular thyroid cancer is bifurcated according to age >45 years or <45 years with the younger patients doing better. For patients <45 years old, any T-stage, any N-stage are at most stage II and this is if distant metastases are present. Patients with papillary/follicular cancer rarely die of their disease. Bierwaltes (1) has shown that the death rate for papillary thyroid cancer is 2.4% and for follicular thyroid cancer is 3.1% with surgery and 131I ablation. External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) may be used after 131I ablation in tumors that are nonfunctional (2). In certain clinical situations, the addition of EBRT improves locoregional control and disease-free survival but not overall survival (3). Radioactive iodine concentrates in the salivary glands. Nagada, et al. showed that the risk of sialadenitis following 131I administration was reduced if the patient started using lemon drops within 48 hours (4).

question: What is the best evidence-based initial treatment for a 60-year-old patient with newly diagnosed WHO grade III anaplastic astrocytoma?
c: Chemotherapy or radiation therapy, with unused modality at progression
d: Concurrent chemoradiation therapy, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy
subject: CNS
citations: Wick W, Hartmann C, Engel C, et al. NOA-04 randomized phase III trial of sequential radiochemotherapy of anaplastic glioma with procarbazine, lomustine, and vincristine or temozolomide. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 2009;27:5874-5880.
rationale: Few randomized data exist for patients with grade III astrocytomas. Although commonly used in clinical practice, no randomized data exist for the use of the Stupp protocol (concurrent chemoradiotherapy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy) for anaplastic astrocytomas. The NOA-04 trial showed in 318 patients that the use of chemotherapy first (PCV or TMZ) has equivalent time to treatment failure as compared to radiation therapy first. Patients crossed over to the other modality at the time of progression. The use of concurrent chemoradiotherapy is investigational and being studied on protocol (EORTC 26053/22054).

question: Which of the following problems is demonstrated when there is considerable variation in repeated measurements of the same subjects using the same study methods under the same lab conditions?
subject: Statistics
rationale: The method has poor repeatability if there is considerable variation in repeated measurements on the same subject. Lack of agreement is used to compare the agreement between two methods. Reproducibility is the variability introduced into the measurement system by the bias differences of different methods. Selection bias is a bias introduced by the nonrandom process of selecting the patients in the study. This affects the generalizability (external validity) of a study but not its (internal) validity.

question: Adult stem cells lack which characteristic?
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: Adult stem cells can be unipotent, multipotent, or in some cases, even pluripotent; however, only extremely early-stage embryonic stem cells are considered to be totipotent (that is, able to generate all embryonic and adult cell types). Adult stem cells do self-renew (as well as give rise to progenitor cells), are largely undifferentiated, and have the enzyme telomerase active, which confers on them replicative immortality.

question: The CALGB 39801 randomized trial demonstrated that the use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in addition to concurrent chemoradiation in patients with unresectable locally advanced NSCLC:
a: improved progression-free survival, but not overall survival.
b: improved distant metastatic-free survival, but not overall survival.
c: increased the rate of grade 3 esophagitis.
d: increased the rate of hematologic toxicity.
subject: Thorax
rationale: In the CALGB 39801 trial, it randomized patients with unresectable locally advanced NSCLC to neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by chemoradiation or definitive chemoradiation alone. There was no improvement in progression-free survival (PFS) or overall survival (OS) with the addition of neoadjuvant chemotherapy. There was increased hematologic toxicity but not esophagitis with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

question: Which cranial neuropathy treatment would be most appropriate for a patient who has breast cancer with leptomeningeal disease and a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt?
subject: Palliative
citations: Harris JR (editor). Leptomeningeal metastasis. Diseases of the Breast, 4th ed. 2010. p 1004.
rationale: Corticosteroids rarely improve neurological function in patients with leptomeningeal (LM) disease as there is little edema in the underlying brain parenchyma. Steroids can improve any symptoms associated with increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment includes radiation plus chemotherapy, intrathecal or systemic. Whole-brain radiation therapy (WBRT) can enhance neurotoxicity of chemotherapy administered into the CSF and should be used only when the patient has symptoms from the brain or cranial nerves or when cranial CSF flow is obstructed. Intrathecal chemotherapy should not be given with concurrent WBRT to reduce the risk of neurotoxicity. Radiation is effective in treating a region of LM disease, and chemotherapy is recommended for treatment of the subarachnoid space. Intrathecal chemotherapy is not administered to patients who have had placement of a VP shunt.

question: Which of the following treatments would be most appropriate for primary ovarian cancer?
a: Whole abdominal irradiation for stage I or II epithelial cancer
b: Surgery combined with radiation therapy for stage I or II dysgerminoma
c: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy for stage III epithelial cancer
d: Whole abdominal irradiation for stage III dysgerminoma
subject: Gyn
citations: http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/treatment/ovarian.
rationale: Understanding the role of radiation therapy in the treatment of ovarian cancer is important for the radiation oncologist. Radiation is most appropriate for early-stage dysgerminoma. Chemotherapy is the preferred treatment for epithelial cancers and more advanced dysgerminomas.

question: What is the most common histologic subtype for rhabdomyosarcoma of the extremities?
subject: Pediatrics
rationale: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common histologic subtype for rhabdomyosarcoma of the extremities. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is more common in the orbit, head and neck, and pelvis. Botryoid rhabdomyosarcoma is most commonly diagnosed in the vagina.

question: A Klatskin tumor is best defined as a:
a: liver metastasis involving the portal vein.
b: hepatocellular carcinoma in a cirrhotic liver.
c: gallbladder carcinoma involving the cystic duct.
d: cholangiocarcinoma involving the confluence of right and left hepatic bile ducts.
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: A Klatskin tumor is defined as a cholangiocarcinoma that involves the confluence of the right and left hepatic bile ducts.

question: Which maximum effective radiation dose equivalent correctly matches its population group?
a: 0.1 mSv/year to members of the general public
b: 0.5 mSv/year to members of the general public
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Hall and Giaccia. Radbio for the Radiologist. 6th ed. Chapter 15.
rationale: A radiation worker is permitted up to 50 mSv per year, provided the cumulative exposure limit of the worker's age multiplied by 10 mSv is not exceeded. A pregnant radiation worker is allowed a maximum of 0.5 mSv per month of continuous exposure after the pregnancy is declared. Members of the general public are allowed 1 mSv per year of continuous exposure and 5 mSv per year for a one-time, infrequent exposure.

question: Which criteria are included in the post-rituximab Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index (FLIPI)?
a: Age, tumor size, bone marrow involvement, extranodal involvement, and serum hemoglobin level
b: Age, tumor size, bone marrow involvement, ?2-microglobulin, and serum hemoglobin level
c: Age, tumor size, bone marrow involvement, performance status, and LDH serum level
d: Age, tumor size, bone marrow involvement, extranodal involvement, and LDH serum level
subject: Lymphoma
citations: Federico M, et al. Follicular lymphoma international prognostic index 2: a new prognostic index for follicular lymphoma developed by the international follicular lymphoma prognostic factor project. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 2009;Sep 20;27(27):4555-62.
rationale: The following factors are found to be predictive of outcome in patients with follicular lymphoma: Age, tumor size, bone marrow involvement, ?2-microglobulin, and serum hemoglobin level.

question: A study is designed to determine if treatment decreases total serum cholesterol levels. Participants in the study have a mean total serum cholesterol level of 250 mg/dL at baseline, which decreases to 180 mg/dL after 6 months of treatment. Which type of test and null hypothesis (H0) findings best describe this analysis?
a: Two-tailed test, (H0) = total serum cholesterol level not decreased by treatment
b: Two-tailed test, (H0) = total serum cholesterol level decreased by treatment
c: One-tailed test, (H0) = total serum cholesterol level not decreased by treatment
d: One-tailed test, (H0) = total serum cholesterol level decreased by treatment
subject: Statistics
rationale: The null hypothesis H0: d = 0; the alternative hypothesis H1: d < 0, where d denotes the total cholesterol level difference between the baseline and end of study. This is a left-tailed test since it emphasizes the "decrease" instead of any difference.

question: In modern medical electron linear accelerators, all photon beams must pass through which device before they can be used clinically?
subject: Physics
citations: Khan F. The Physics of Radiation Therapy. 4th ed.
rationale: Medical electron linear accelerators used in modern radiation oncology departments generate photon beams by accelerating an electron beam to high energies and bombarding the beam into an x-ray target to produce bremsstrahlung radiation. A scattering foil is needed if electrons are intended to be used clinically. Although a flattening filter is typically used for most photon treatments, a number of new linear accelerators have a flattening filter-free treatment mode. Lastly, tertiary collimators (i.e., MLC) are not necessary for all photon treatments. There are still a number of treatments delivered with open fields in which the field aperture is only defined by the x and y collimator jaws.

question: Which management option would be most appropriate for a patient with stage IAE gastric MALT?
a: Anti-Helicobacter pylori therapy for patients with negative results for Helicobacter pylori
b: Definitive radiation for patients with negative results for Helicobacter pylori
c: R-CHOP for patients with positive results for Helicobacter pylori and a t(14:18) translocation
d: Total gastrectomy, followed by close observation
subject: Lymphoma
citations: Tsang, et al. J Clin Oncol. 2003 Nov 15;21(22):4157-64. Yamashita H, et al. Radiother Oncol. 2008 Jun;87(3):412-7. Radiotherapy is indicated in H. Pylori negative or H. Pylori treatment refractory cases. Windisch T, et al. Leuk Lymphoma. 2006 Oct;47(10):2110-4. Liu H, et al. Lancet. 2001 Jan 6;357(9249):39-40.
rationale: Anti-Helicobacter pylori therapy is most effective for patients who have positive results for Helicobacter pylori (H. Pylori) disease. Radiation therapy is one of the most effective modalities in treating gastric mucosal-associate lymphoid tumor (MALT) for H. Pylori-negative cases of persistent disease. A translocation status of t(14:18) is predictive of a poor response to anti-H. Pylori therapy, and radiation therapy may be indicated as first-line therapy. Recent evidence also suggests that t (11; 18) is associated with resistance to H. Pylori therapy.

question: According to results of the randomized trial reported by Keime-Guibert, which treatment regimen is most likely to improve survival in a 75-year-old patient who has newly diagnosed glioblastoma multiforme and a Karnofsky performance score (KPS) of 80?
a: 60 Gy of radiation over 6 weeks versus 40 Gy of radiation over 3 weeks
b: 60 Gy of radiation with temozolomide versus radiation alone
c: 50.4 Gy of radiation versus best supportive care alone
d: 40 Gy of radiation over 3 weeks with temozolomide versus 40 Gy of radiation over 3 weeks alone
subject: CNS
citations: Stupp R, Hegi ME, Mason WP, et al. Effects of radiotherapy with concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide versus radiotherapy alone on survival in glioblastoma in a randomized phase III study: 5-year analysis of the EORTC-NCIC trial. Lancet Oncol. 2009;10:459-466. Roa W, Brasher PM, Bauman G, et al. Abbreviated course of radiation therapy in older patients with glioblastoma multiforme: a prospective randomized clinical trial. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 2004;22:1583-1588. Keime-Guibert F, Chinot O, Taillandier L, et al. Radiotherapy for glioblastoma in the elderly. New England Journal of Medicine (N Engl J Med). 2007;356:1527-1535.
rationale: The Roa trial demonstrated the same survival outcome with 60 Gy of radiation therapy in 6 weeks as with 40 Gy of radiation in 3 weeks. The Stupp trial did not enroll patients older than 70 years of age. Radiation therapy of 40 Gy in 3 weeks with or without temozolomide (TMZ) is being tested in the current EORTC/NCIC trial. No results are available.

question: The p53 protein is involved either directly or indirectly in all of the following cellular responses to irradiation EXCEPT:
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Levine and Oren. Nat Rev Cancer. 9:749-758.2009.
rationale: The p53 protein is the product of the key tumor suppressor gene, TP53, which plays a fundamental role in the maintenance of genomic stability. It accomplishes this by stimulating the repair of DNA damage after a toxic insult, by initiating apoptosis in cells that harbor irreparable or residual DNA damage, and by coordinating cell cycle progression and DNA repair such that the cell will pause at key points in its cell cycle to allow DNA repair to progress, thereby preventing the propagation of genetic errors to cellular progeny. Although the p53 protein also plays multiple roles in the regulation of angiogenesis, it functions as an angiogenesis inhibitor, NOT a promoter.

question: Based on the Oxford Overview, postmastectomy radiation therapy will improve overall survival in patients with breast cancer and a minimum locoregional recurrence risk of:
subject: Breast
citations: Early Breast Cancer Trialist's Collaborative Group. Effects of radiotherapy and differences in extent of surgery for early breast cancer on local recurrences and 15-year survival: an overview of randomized trials. Lancet 2005;366:2087-2106. Harris JR, ed. Diseases of the Breast, 4th ed. Epidemiology, Assessing and Managing Risk, 2010. pp 540-541.
rationale: Any patient who is expected to have a 10% or greater reduction in locoregional recurrence (LR) with radiation will have a significant reduction in long-term mortality. Since postmastectomy radiation therapy (RT) proportionately reduces LR by 70%, this would correspond to a minimum risk of 15% LR in the absence of RT.

question: What type of image is created using the planning CT dataset to compare with port films taken at the treatment machine to verify patient setup?
subject: Physics
rationale: Using the linear attenuation coefficient data in the planning CT data set, one can mathematically reconstruct a beam's eye view for any beam. This is called a digitally reconstructed radiograph (or DRR) and can be used to compare with port films taken on the treatment machine.

question: Definitive therapy for patients with advanced unresected vulvar cancer should involve:
a: concurrent 5 FU or cisplatin with radiation therapy.
b: a curative radiation dose of 70 Gy to the gross tumor.
c: chemoradiation therapy for a complete pathologic response rate of 90%.
d: chemoradiation therapy not followed by resection.
subject: Gyn
rationale: Curative radiation dose to the vulva is usually between 62-65 Gy. Higher doses can cause tissue necrosis. The complete response is usually 50% in most reported series following chemoradiation. Either cisplatin or 5 FU is acceptable for concurrent treatment with radiation.

question: Which subtype of rhabdomyosarcoma is associated with t(2;13)?
subject: Pediatrics
rationale: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (ARMS) is associated with t(2;13). Translocation of t(2;13)(q35;q14) generates PAX3 - FOXO1 in ~60% of ARMS cases. Translocation of t(1;13)(p36;q14) generates PAX7 - FOXO1 in ~20% of ARMS cases. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (ERMS) does not have recurrent structural chromosome rearrangements, but rather has frequent chromosomal gains and losses. In addition, ERMS has a much higher frequency of loss of one of the two alleles of many chromosome 11 loci, particularly in the 11p15.5 region.

question: Which statement about radiation-induced liver disease is true?
a: Initial symptoms appear 2 to 3 years after radiation therapy.
b: Dexamethasone is the standard treatment for the disease.
c: Clinical features include anicteric ascites, hepatomegaly, and elevated alkaline phosphatase.
d: Pathogenesis of the disease is due to acute inflammation of hepatocytes.
subject: GI
citations: Krishnan, et al. Radiation Oncology Rationale, Technique, Results. 9th ed.
rationale: Radiation-induced liver disease (RILD) is a subacute process. Option A: Typically, symptoms appear 2 weeks to 3 months after completion of radiation therapy. Option B: Currently, there is no standard therapy for RILD; most patients are treated with supportive care, diuretics, and paracentesis. Option C: Clinical features include anicteric ascites, tender hepatomegaly, and elevated liver enzymes. Alkaline phosphatase levels are often elevated out of proportion to the transaminases or bilirubin. Option D: Radiation-induced liver disease is manifested by veno-occlusive disease with central vein thrombosis. This results in retrograde congestion leading to hemorrhage and secondary alterations in surrounding hepatocytes.

question: What patient management technique is most likely to substantially reduce the ITV margin for conventionally fractionated lung tumor treatments?
c: Placing the patient in a prone position during treatment
d: CT simulation in a vacuum bag
subject: Physics
citations: Nelson, et al. Evaluation of Tumor Position and PTV Margins Using Image Guidance and Respiratory Gating. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 2010 Apr;76(5):1578-1585.
rationale: Respiratory motion management is the most effective way to reduce the necessary ITV margin for a fractionated lung treatment. Immobilization during simulation does not influence the size of the PTV. Although image-guidance during setup can be used to reduce the necessary PTV margin utilized for treatment planning, it does this by reducing the setup margin, not the margin associated with internal motion.

question: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 40-year-old man with stage IAE, Helicobacter pylori-negative, marginal zone lymphoma of the stomach?
b: R-CHOP x 3 cycles and 30 Gy of involved-field irradiation
c: R-CHOP x 3 cycles and 40 Gy of involved-field irradiation
subject: Lymphoma
rationale: Radiation therapy alone is standard for marginal zone lymphoma, which results in 90% local control.

question: Which statement about nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) of DNA double strand breaks is true?
b: A defect in NHEJ leads to immune deficiency.
c: It occurs predominantly during the S phase of the cell cycle.
d: The NBS/MRE11/Rad50 protein complex is involved in "end recognition.
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: V(D)J recombination is the process whereby segments of immunoglobulin genes and T-cell receptors are rearranged during development of the vertebrate immune system. V(D)J recombination is initiated by the introduction of a DNA single strand break at specific sites by the RAG1/RAG2 protein complex. The single strand break is then converted to a DNA double strand break, which is repaired during the process of V(D)J recombination by the NHEJ machinery. Therefore, defective NHEJ also leads to immune deficiency. NHEJ occurs predominantly in the G1 phase of the cell cycle and is inherently error prone because it does not have access to the undamaged chromatid/chromosome as a template. The NBS/MRE11/Rad50 complex is involved in "end processing," while Ku70, Ku80, and DNA-PKcs are involved in "end recognition.

question: What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for a patient with a 3 cm renal cell carcinoma limited to the right kidney without evidence of metastatic disease?
b: Radiation therapy to the right kidney
subject: GU
citations: Campbell, et al. Journal of Urology (J Urol). 2009;182:1271-1279.
rationale: Surgical resection (either a partial nephrectomy, if possible, or a radical nephrectomy) should be first-line treatment for a stage I renal cell carcinoma. Radiation therapy is not used as primary therapy for localized renal cell carcinoma.

question: When designing the necessary radiation shielding for a vault, the first half value layer (HVL) for a 6 MV beam compared to subsequent HVLs will be:
subject: Physics
rationale: As polychromatic beams penetrate material, low-energy particles are preferentially attenuated, resulting in a harder beam. As a result, each successive HVL will be larger than the previous HVL.

question: What is the risk of occult nodal disease for a patient with early-stage (T1 or T2) squamous cell carcinoma of the hypopharynx?
subject: H&N
citations: El Badawi, et al. Laryngoscopy. 1982;92:357-364.
rationale: Occult nodal disease is found in about 60% of patients with early-stage disease and 85% of patients with advanced disease.

question: In the reanalysis of the ANITA trial for NSCLC, the overall survival was improved with the use of postoperative radiation therapy in patients who had:
a: pathologic stage N1 disease and received adjuvant chemotherapy.
b: pathologic stage N1 disease and did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy.
c: pathologic stage T3N0 disease and did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy.
d: any pathologic stage N+ disease regardless of chemotherapy.
subject: Thorax
rationale: In the reanalysis of the Adjuvant Navelbine International Trialist Association (ANITA) trial, overall, there was a detrimental effect on overall survival (OS) with postoperative radiation therapy (PORT). However, in a subset analysis, PORT improved survival in patients who had stage pN1 and did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy and was detrimental in those who received chemotherapy. Improved OS was seen in patients who had stage pN2 with or without adjuvant chemotherapy.

question: According to the NCCN Breast Cancer Guidelines, PET scans or PET-CT scans are recommended for:
b: initial staging of patients with inoperable stage III breast cancer.
c: initial staging of patients with high-risk clinical stage II breast cancer.
d: any clinical stage when other staging studies are equivocal.
subject: Breast
citations: NCNN Guidelines, 2011.
rationale: The use of PET or PET-CT scanning is generally discouraged for the evaluation of metastatic disease, except in those clinical situations where other staging studies are equivocal or suspicious. Even in these situations, biopsy of equivocal or suspicious sites is more likely to provide useful information.

question: Which radiation dose regimen is used for stage I, group 3 orbital embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma?
subject: Pediatrics
rationale: A dose of 45 Gy in 25 fractions is used in orbital rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS). In the IRS I study, it was noted that patients with orbital RMS did well without a complete resection; therefore, on further studies, resection was not recommended after IRS II. Local control for these patients is over 90%.

question: What is the posterior anatomical boundary of the parametrium?
a: Posterior border of the external iliac vessel
c: Medial edge of the internal obturator muscle
subject: Gyn
citations: Consensus guidelines for delineation of clinical target volume for intensity-modulated pelvic radiotherapy for the definitive treatment of cervix cancer. Table 3. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 2011;79(2):348-355.
rationale: Anatomical boundaries of parametria: Anteriorly: Posterior wall of bladder or posterior border of external iliac vessel. Posteriorly: Uterosacral ligaments and mesorectal fascia. Laterally: Medial edge of internal obturator muscle/ ischial ramus bilaterally. Superiorly: Top of fallopian tube/ broad ligament. Depending on degree of uterus flexion, this may also form the anterior boundary of parametrial tissue. Inferiorly: Urogenital diaphragm.

question: The Child Pugh classification of liver failure includes which of the following factors?
a: Bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy, albumin, and prothrombin time
b: Bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy, LDH, and prothrombin time
c: Bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy, albumin, and platelet count
d: Bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy, alkaline phosphatase, and platelet count
subject: GI
citations: DeVita, 7th ed, page 997.
rationale: The Child Pugh classification of liver failure incorporates bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy, albumin, and prothrombin time.

question: Which radiation dose is the standard of care for patients who have glioblastoma with residual disease?
subject: CNS
citations: Walker MD, Strike TA, Sheline GE. An analysis of dose-effect relationship in the radiotherapy of malignant gliomas. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 1979;5:1725-1731. Souhami L, Seiferheld W, Brachman D, et al. Randomized comparison of stereotactic radiosurgery followed by conventional radiotherapy with carmustine to conventional radiotherapy with carmustine for patients with glioblastoma multiforme: report of Radiation Therapy Oncology Group 93-05 protocol. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys. 2004;60:853. Stupp R, Hegi ME, Mason WP, et al. Effects of radiotherapy with concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide versus radiotherapy alone on survival in glioblastoma in a randomised phase III study: 5-year analysis of the EORTC-NCIC trial. Lancet Oncol. 2009;10:459-466.860.
rationale: Retrospective analyses of multiple Brain Tumor Study Group trials reveal a dose response with improved survival at 60 Gy compared to lesser doses of 55, 50, and 0 Gy. The current standard of care (Stupp trial) used 60 Gy. There is no benefit to dose escalation with SRS preceding 60 Gy of radiotherapy, per RTOG 93-05.

question: Apoptosis is best described as:
a: a process that helps to maintain tissue homeostasis.
b: a process that, once initiated, spreads to all cells with a similar genetic background.
c: a suicide program most commonly activated by neighboring cells.
d: the principal form of radiobiological cell death.
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Alberts, Johnson, Lewis, et al. Molecular Biology of the Cell. 4th ed. Chapter 21.
rationale: Apoptosis, one of several types of radiobiological cell death (others include mitotic catastrophe, necrosis, autophagy, and senescence), occurs when a 'suicide' program is activated within the cell, leading to fragmentation of the DNA, shrinkage of the cytoplasm, membrane changes, and cell death, without lysis and consequent damage to neighboring cells. It is a natural process that occurs frequently in multicellular organisms; it functions during embryogenesis to help "sculpt" tissues. It is also involved throughout life helping to maintain tissue homeostasis and eliminate damaged, potentially dangerous cells. Apoptosis is triggered in response to internal or external cellular stimuli and not by neighboring cells per se, nor is it "transferrable" to genetically similar cells. Most irradiated cells die by mitotic catastrophe, although a few types do die preferentially by mitosis (e.g., lymphocytes).

question: What is the advantage of kV CBCT over 2D electronic portal imaging when assessing a patient's setup and interfraction variations?
subject: Physics
citations: AAPM Task Group (TG)
rationale: The advantage of CBCT over 2D imaging is the high soft tissue contrast. As such, patients can be positioned based on soft tissue, and the deformation of organs can be assessed. However, CBCT images require more time to acquire, deliver higher imaging doses to patients (~ 30-80 mGy compared to 1-2 mGy for a pelvic exam), and may contain artifacts that are inherent with the rotational delivery of x-rays. For instance, crescent artifacts result from the motion of the bowtie filter during the acquisition of CBCT projections.

question: How many patients would need to receive chemoprevention treatment to keep one person from getting cancer if the absolute risk reduction is 0.01?
subject: Statistics
citations: Basic and Clinical Biostatistics, 4th ed, Chapter 3, page 52.
rationale: The number needed for chemoprevention treatment to prevent one event is the reciprocal of absolute risk reduction or 1/ARR. In this example, 1/0.01 = 100. This type of information helps clinicians evaluate the relative risks and benefits of a particular treatment.

question: If a large number of individuals were exposed to radiation during a nuclear power plant accident, which cytogenetic assay of peripheral blood lymphocytes would provide the best estimate of the dose received?
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Hall and Giaccia. Radbio for the Radiologist. 6th ed. Chapter 2.
rationale: Currently, dicentric chromosomes are the assay of choice for biological dosimetry. They require no special preparation, are easy to score, and are unambiguous. Most importantly, the background frequency of these aberrations is extremely low. In the future, the counting of micronuclei could become important as these might better lend themselves to automated scoring and the attendant increase in speed, efficiency, and throughput.

question: Which study reported a statistically significant overall survival advantage with the addition of involved-field radiation therapy to systemic chemotherapy for patients with early-stage non-Hodgkin lymphoma?
subject: Lymphoma
citations: Horning, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology (JCO). 2004. Miller, et al. New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM). 1998. Bonnet, et al. JCO. 2007.
rationale: Only the initial report from the SWOG study showed an overall survival advantage with the addition of involved-field radiation therapy to systemic chemotherapy for patients with early-stage non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

question: Which T stage would be most appropriate for an upper urothelial tract carcinoma with invasion into the periureteric fat?
subject: GU
rationale: AJCC T staging for renal pelvic and upper tract urothelial cancers is based on depth of invasion. Invasion in to the periureteric fat is considered T3 disease.

question: What is the dominant photon interaction responsible for dose deposition in photon radiation therapy energies (roughly 1-20 MV) in human tissue?
subject: Physics
rationale: It is important to know that the Compton effect is the dominant interaction for therapeutic energies for low atomic number materials (air, water) making up body tissues. The energy absorption coefficient for the Compton effect is much greater than any of the other photon interaction coefficients in the energy range of 20 keV to 30 MeV for low Z materials.

question: Which statement about squamous cell carcinoma of the pyriform sinus is true?
a: Level 4 lymph node involvement is most common.
b: Involvement of the apex of the pyriform sinus has the best prognosis.
c: Referred ear pain is usually related to involvement of the superior laryngeal nerve.
d: Subclinical lymph node involvement will be found pathologically in 20% of cases.
subject: H&N
rationale: Understanding the anatomy of pyriform sinus cancers is important to ensure that the practitioner understands the volume necessary to be treated. The apex is located at the bottom of the cricoid. Tumor involvement of the apex poses a worse prognosis as compared to other sites of the pyriform sinus; occult lymph nodes are seen in 60% of cases, and involvement of level 2 lymph nodes is most common.

question: According to results of the Stupp trial, which survival outcome was demonstrated in patients who received chemoradiation therapy for glioblastoma with methylated MGMT status?
subject: CNS
citations: Hegi ME, Diserens AC, Gorlia T, et al. MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma. New England Journal of Medicine (N Engl J Med). 2005;352:997-1003. Stupp R, Hegi ME, Mason WP, et al. Effects of radiotherapy with concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide versus radiotherapy alone on survival in glioblastoma in a randomized phase III study: 5-year analysis of the EORTC-NCIC trial. Lancet Oncol. 2009;10:459-466.
rationale: Epigenetic silencing of the MGMT DNA repair gene by promoter methylation compromises DNA repair and has been associated with longer survival in patients who receive alkylating agents for glioblastoma. Option C is the correct answer for radiation therapy alone (without chemotherapy): 3-year overall survival is 28 vs 11 months for MGMT methylated vs unmethylated for combined chemoradiotherapy.

question: What is the proposed mechanism of action of EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies?
a: Induction of receptor internalization and nuclear translocation
b: Induction of an immune response against the tyrosine kinase domain
c: Inhibition of ligand binding and receptor dimerization
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Baumann, et al. Radiother Oncol. 83: 238-48, 2007. Harari, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 25: 4057-4065, 2007.
rationale: Antibodies against EGFR are used in the clinic to radiosensitize tumors. The precise mechanisms underlying the radiosensitization remain somewhat unclear but may include inhibition of ligand binding and receptor dimerization, receptor internalization and degradation, prevention of nuclear translocation to promote DNA repair, or antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.

question: Which statistical quantity decreases as the number of measurements increases?
subject: Statistics
rationale: The standard error of the mean is the standard deviation of the distribution divided by the square root of the number of measurements. Thus, as the number of measurements increases, the uncertainty in the mean value of the distribution decreases.

question: Which statement about the diagnostic procedure for malignant pleural mesothelioma is true?
a: Serum osteopontin levels provide high sensitivity but low specificity as a diagnostic marker.
b: Cytologic analysis of the pleural fluid is effective for diagnosis in 90% of cases.
c: Fine needle aspiration is preferred because it reduces the risk of tumor seeding.
d: Loss of tumor suppressor genes BRCA2 and NF1 are pathognomonic.
subject: Thorax
rationale: Cytologic analysis of pleural fluid has a low (<30%) diagnostic yield for diagnosis of malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM), whereas osteopontin has high sensitivity but low specificity as a diagnostic marker. Mesothelin has high specificity for epithelioid MPM. VATS and open biopsies are preferred as diagnostic procedures for MPM, and there is minimal evidence that fine needle aspiration (FNA) may decrease the probability of tumor seeding. Loss of p16, p14, NF2, p53, and WT are common in MPM.

question: Radiation therapy is indicated to begin the first week after chemotherapy for patients who have rhabdomyosarcoma:
subject: Pediatrics
rationale: Direct intracranial extension is an indication for radiation therapy to begin at week 1 of the course of treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma in both IRS-V and IRS-VI.

question: According to the American Brachytherapy Society guidelines for LDR implants for Cervix cancer, the lateral vaginal dose should be reported for the:
c: unilateral vaginal surface and 0.5 cm deep to the vaginal surface.
d: bilateral vaginal surface and 0.5 cm deep to the vaginal surface.
subject: Gyn
citations: The American Brachytherapy Society (ABS) Recommendations for Low-Dose-Rate Brachytherapy for Carcinoma of the Cervix. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 2002;52(1):33-48.
rationale: The ABS recommends reporting the dose at the lateral vaginal surface (mucosa)/(points Vs) and at 0.5 cm deep to the vaginal surface (point Vd). Points Vs and Vd shall be specified separately for the right and left side. The ABS suggests limiting the Vs dose to less than 150% of the point A dose.

question: According to an 8-year analysis of the NSABP B18 and B27 trials, what was the cumulative incidence of axillary recurrence in patients who had node-positive breast cancer and received neoadjuvant chemotherapy, lumpectomy, and breast irradiation that excluded the regional lymph nodes?
subject: Breast
citations: Harris JR (editor). Local-regional therapy considerations in patients receiving preoperative chemotherapy. Diseases of the Breast. 4th ed. 2010. pp 740-741.
rationale: On multivariate analysis, predictors of locoregional recurrence (LRR) included the clinical tumor size and nodal status before preoperative chemotherapy and pathologic breast or nodal tumor response after preoperative chemotherapy. Patients with node negative/pCR breast cancer demonstrated a 5.6% breast cancer recurrence and 1.2% regional recurrence. Patients with node negative/no pCR breast cancer demonstrated a 5.9% breast cancer recurrence and 1.1% regional recurrence. Patients with node positive disease regardless of breast tumor response demonstrated a 6.4% breast cancer recurrence and 3.4% regional recurrence.

question: A 50-year-old man has stage T3N2 rectal adenocarcinoma with two liver metastases. Which statement about this patient's condition is true?
a: The patient's disease is classified as AJCC stage IVB.
b: No effective chemotherapy regimen exists for colorectal liver metastases.
c: Resection of liver metastases may provide long-term survival in selected patients.
d: SBRT and surgical resection are equally effective in providing local control of liver metastases.
subject: GI
citations: AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. 7th ed. 2009. Kopetz, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology (JCO). 2009.
rationale: Option A: The AJCC stage for colorectal cancer with multiple metastases to a single organ is IVA. Option B: Chemotherapy can be effective in the setting of metastatic colorectal cancer. Option C: Liver resection can lead to long-term survival in selected patients. Profound improvements in outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer have been attributed to an increase in the use of hepatic resection and improved chemotherapy. Option D: To date, there are no randomized controlled studies comparing the efficacy of SBRT and surgical resection of liver metastases.

question: Ring structures are often created around PTVs in IMRT planning. Maximum dose constraints are set for these rings during IMRT dose optimization to:
a: confine the high dose to the PTV volume.
b: avoid the dose to distant OAR regions.
c: minimize hot spots in the PTV volume.
subject: Physics
rationale: A ring structure is commonly used in planning IMRT. A maximum dose is allowed for the ring to force the high isodose levels to conform to the PTV volume. Ring structures around targets would not influence the dose to distant structures. Dose constraints on the individual organs at risk (OAR) are more effective to limit the dose to the OAR. A ring structure will not help with hot spots in the PTV. The ring is not used to affect the delivery time.

question: The yield of hydrogen peroxide from the radiolysis of water is higher for high LET radiation than for low LET radiation because:
a: molecular oxygen is also ionized after high LET radiation and interacts with the radiolysis products of water.
b: the higher density of free radicals produced in high LET tracks facilitates radical-radical interactions.
c: hydrogen peroxide is produced during apoptosis, which occurs with greater frequency after exposure to high LET radiation.
d: hydrogen peroxide is a byproduct of the more severe DNA damage caused by high LET radiation.
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: The damaging effects of ionizing radiation stem principally from its ability to cause the ejection of electrons from molecules within the cell, particularly water molecules, given their high abundance. This leads to the production of a number of free radical species, including hydrogen atoms, hydrated electrons and hydroxyl radicals that go on to react with additional cellular macromolecules. However, should these reactive species be produced at very high density, as would be the case for high LET but not low LET radiation, the likelihood of the free radicals reacting with each other would be increased, such that so-called "molecular products" including hydrogen peroxide and hydrogen gas, would have a higher probability of being created. Hydrogen peroxide is neither a byproduct of DNA damage nor apoptosis, and while molecular oxygen theoretically could be ionized after high LET radiation, its subsequent interactions with the radiolysis products of water would not yield hydrogen peroxide.

question: A 55-year-old man underwent a right lower lobe lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node dissection for a 3.5 cm NSCLC with negative margins. There were two positive right hilar lymph nodes with no evidence of mediastinal or distant metastasis. Which adjuvant treatment would be most appropriate for this patient?
subject: Thorax
citations: Pignon JP, Tribodet H, Scagliotti GV, et al. Lung adjuvant cisplatin evaluation: a pooled analysis by the LACE Collaborative Group. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 2008;26(21):3552-9. PORT Meta-analysis Trialists Group. Postoperative radiotherapy in non small cell lung cancer: systematic review and meta-analysis of individual patient data from nine randomized clinical trials. Lancet. 1995;352:257-263. Lally B, Zelterman D, Colasanto J, et al. Postoperative radiotherapy for stage I or II non-small cell lung cancer using the surveillance, epidemiology, and end results database. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 2006;24:2998-3006.
rationale: According to the AJCC 7th edition of the cancer staging manual, the TNM stage for this case is stage T2aN1M0 (IIA). Postoperative cisplatin-based chemotherapy significantly improves survival in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) corresponding to a 5-year absolute benefit of 5.4% from chemotherapy. The postoperative radiation therapy meta-analysis has been widely discussed because of the negative effect of radiation therapy in overall survival for all patients examined (stages I-III). A SEER database showed that postoperative radiation therapy resulted in decreased survival for N0 and N1 disease.

question: What are the most common sites of failure after radical nephroureterectomy for TCC of the upper urinary tract?
subject: GU
citations: Hall, et. al. Urology. 1998;54:594-601.
rationale: Approximately 50% of patients with urothelial carcinoma of the ureters will fail in the bladder, due to the panurothelial nature of the urinary tract and field cancerization of the transitional epithelium. Distant failure is also relatively common (~25% in unselected series) and suggests the need for adjuvant systemic therapy, especially in patients with locally advanced disease. Meanwhile, the risk of local relapse in the retroperitoneum after radical nephroureterectomy is fairly low (~10%), such that consideration of adjuvant radiation therapy is not common and less likely to impact survival.

question: Following an LDR brachytherapy implant, the delivered dose was discovered to be in excess of the planned dose by 25%. According to the NRC, this incident currently would be classified as a:
subject: Physics
rationale: According to 10 CFR 35.3045, an event that results in the total delivered dose deviating from the prescribed dose by 20% or more is known as a medical event. Prior to April 2002, the term "misadministration" was used to classify this event. The term "misadventure" was used by AAPM TG-59 to denote such events, but this term has not been adopted nationally and was not used by the NRC. 10CFR20.2203 discusses "reportable events;" however, these are events related to dose received by radiation workers and/or members of the general public, not to patients.

question: A 55-year-old man presents with large squamous cell carcinoma involving his left maxillary sinus, with invasion of the left nasal cavity and bone of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus extending superiorly into the ethmoid sinuses. The orbit was not involved, and no nodal disease was evident. Which treatment would be most appropriate?
c: Maxillectomy, followed by radiation therapy to the primary site
subject: H&N
citations: (1) Le Q-T, Fu KK, Kaplan MJ, et al. Lymph node metastasis in maxillary sinus carcinoma. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 2000;46: 541-549. (2) Jeremic B, Shibamoto Y, Milicic B, et al. Elective ipsilateral neck irradiation of patients with locally advanced maxillary sinus carcinoma. Cancer. 2000;88: 2246-2251. (3) Bristol IJ, Ahamad A, Oswald MJ, et al. Postoperative radiation for maxillary sinus carcinoma: does elective nodal irradiation affect regional control? Int. J. Radiation Oncology Biol. Phys. Vol. 63, Suppl. 1, pp. S75 (124), 2005. (4) AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th ed, Springer, 2010.
rationale: Surgery followed by radiation therapy is the treatment of choice for patients with locally advanced resectable squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the maxillary sinus. Whenever feasible, an attempt should be made to spare the orbit if it is not involved. Overall incidence of lymphadenopathy at diagnosis for maxillary sinus cancers is <10%. However, rates of neck failure without elective treatment have been reported to range from 8% to 33% [1-3]. Nodal risk does appear to vary by histology and is higher for squamous cell carcinoma and poorly differentiated or undifferentiated carcinomas. Several groups have reported that elective neck radiation reduces the risk of nodal relapse by 20% to 30% and should be considered in patients with stage T3-T4 squamous cell carcinoma or undifferentiated carcinomas [1-3]. This patient has clinical stage T3N0 disease, which includes tumor invasion into any of the following: bone of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, subcutaneous tissues, floor or medial wall of the orbit, pterygoid fossa, and ethmoid sinuses [4]. Stage T4a disease is defined by tumor invasion into the anterior orbital contents, skin of the cheek, pterygoid plates, infratemporal fossa, cribriform plate, sphenoid or frontal sinuses.

question: What is the most common visual defect associated with craniopharyngioma?
b: Pie in the sky visual defect
subject: CNS
rationale: Craniopharyngioma can cause a mass effect on the optic chiasm that leads to a bitemporal visual field deficit.

question: Small interfering RNAs (siRNA) primarily function by interfering with:
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: Small interfering RNAs (siRNA) are a new class of biological therapeutics, which function by interfering with gene expression at the translational level. They lead to the rapid degradation of specific mRNA transcripts that they target, preventing translation from occurring.

question: The "power" of a test refers to the:
a: confidence level selected to compare two datasets.
b: precision to which the mean of a distribution can be known.
c: accuracy to which the true mean of a distribution can be known.
d: probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false.
subject: Statistics
citations: Dawson B and Trapp RG. Basic and Clinical Biostatistics. 4th ed. 2004. pp 109 and 411.
rationale: The power of a test is the probability of detecting a difference that exists. It can be stated as the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is indeed false or concluding that the alternative hypothesis is true when it really is true. It is intimately related to the sample size used in the study.

question: What is the treatment of choice for localized unresectable malignant pleural mesothelioma?
subject: Thorax
citations: Vogelzang NJ, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology (JCO). 2003.
rationale: Although one can argue that treatment is fairly palliative and observation (choice D) is reasonable, combination chemotherapy with cisplatin and pemetrexed (Alimta) is the currently FDA-approved indication for use in patients with localized disease unresectable malignant pleural mesothelioma. This treatment indication is based on the randomized controlled trial comparing single-agent chemotherapy with cisplatin versus combined chemotherapy with cisplatin and pemetrexed. Combination chemotherapy improved patients' response rates (41% vs 17%) and survival outcomes (12 months vs. 9 months). Radiation alone or chemoradiation are not indicated, except for palliation of symptomatic sites.

question: According to the American Brachytherapy Society guidelines for HDR implants for Cervix cancer, where should the tandem optimization points begin in relationship to the superior-most dwell position?
subject: Gyn
citations: The American Brachytherapy Society (ABS) recommendations for high-dose-rate brachytherapy for carcinoma of the cervix: International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 2000;48(1):201-211.
rationale: Tandem optimization points should begin approximately 1 cm inferior to the first (superior-most) dwell position and should continue through a point approximately 1 cm superior to the surface of the vaginal appliance. Optimization of the superior-most dwell position often proves too restrictive, and extending the points further inferiorly conflicts with the optimization to the vagina.

question: Which condition is NOT a risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma?
subject: GI
rationale: All of these are risk factors for development of hepatocellular carcinoma, except tobacco use.

question: Static gantry IMRT plans typically use lower energy versus higher energy photon beams because lower energy photon beams:
a: use fewer MUs for the same prescription.
b: have a deeper dmax and are more penetrating.
c: result in minimal or no neutron dose.
subject: Physics
rationale: The advantage of using lower energy photon beams over higher energy beams is that they result in considerably less or no neutron dose. The total MU for a typical IMRT treatment is 3 to 10 times more than that of conventional treatment. The increased MU results in an increase in neutron dose for higher energy photon beams. Option A is incorrect; lower energy photon beams need more MUs because they do not penetrate as far in tissue. Option B is incorrect because lower energy photon beams have a shallower dmax and are less penetrating than higher energy photons. Option D is incorrect because lower energy beams have a higher skin dose compared to higher energy photon beams.

question: Which statement about necrotic cell death is true?
a: Necrosis does not elicit an inflammatory response.
b: Necrotic cell death occurs one cell at a time.
c: Macrophage phagocytosis is triggered by necrotic cell death.
d: Necrosis involves rupture of the nuclear and cytoplasmic membranes.
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: Necrosis is a cell death mechanism usually elicited in response to nutrient or oxygen deprivation, infection, or exposure to reactive oxygen species or toxins secondary to tissue trauma or the presence of a tumor. It is characterized by the swelling and rupture of cellular membranes. The process of necrosis does not send the same chemical signals to the immune system that cells undergoing apoptosis do, meaning that necrotic cells are not phagocytized by macrophages, leading to the build-up of dead cells. This, in turn, can cause a brisk inflammatory response in the tissue. Necrosis tends to be a regional, potentially self-propagating process, unlike apoptosis, that is a programmed process that occurs on a cell-by-cell basis.

question: Which condition is associated with Bierbeck granules on electron microscopy?
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: Bierbeck granules are ultrastructural features of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

question: A 53-year-old man with stage cT2 bladder cancer undergoes bladder preservation treatment with maximal TURBT followed by concurrent chemoradiation to 45 Gy. Endoscopy after induction chemoradiation reveals a small amount of residual tumor invading into the muscularis. According to NCCN Guidelines, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
subject: GU
citations: NCCN Practice Guidelines in Oncology. 2011.
rationale: A bladder preservation strategy utilizing chemoradiation is an option for certain patients who present with muscle invasive bladder cancers. An important component of bladder preservation is assessing the response of the patient to chemoradiotherapy. Persistent disease seen on endoscopy following an initial course of chemoradiotherapy is an indication for a patient to receive a cystectomy.

question: The decay constant () is defined as:
subject: Physics
rationale: Requires an understanding of the equation for exponential decay. The basic expression is that ?N/N0 (the fractional change in the number of atoms) per unit time (?t) is a constant for each radionuclide. Hence, [?N/N0]/ (?t) = constant (?). Rewritten, it is commonly expressed as ? = [?N/ N0]/?t.

question: According to an 8-year analysis of the NSABP B18 and B27 trials, what was the cumulative incidence of chest wall recurrence after treatment with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, but no postoperative radiation therapy for patients with breast cancer and persisting positive lymph nodes?
subject: Breast
citations: Harris JR (editor). Locoregional therapy considerations in patients receiving preoperative chemotherapy. Diseases of the Breast. 4th ed. 2010. pp 740-741.
rationale: Patients with node-negative/pCR breast cancer demonstrated a 1.5% chest wall recurrence and 4.4% regional recurrence. Patients with node-negative but no pCR breast cancer demonstrated a 5% chest wall recurrence and 3% regional recurrence. Patients with node-positive disease regardless of breast response demonstrated 11.2% chest wall recurrence and 3.7% regional recurrence.

question: What is the advantage of radiographic film over a detector to measure dose for patient specific IMRT QA?
subject: Physics
rationale: Film's main advance is its excellent spatial re.

question: Which site should be routinely biopsied as part of the workup of a patient with a squamous cell carcinoma of a jugulodigastric lymph node?
subject: H&N
rationale: The sites of a directed blind biopsy performed at a direct laryngoscopy (DL) in the workup of an unknown primary are the tonsil, base of tongue, nasopharynx, and pyriform sinus.

question: What is the most common complication after surgery for craniopharyngioma?
subject: CNS
rationale: Diabetes insipidus is a common, often temporary, complication after surgery for craniopharyngioma because of manipulation of the infundibulum (pituitary stalk). CSF leak, visual loss, and short-term memory changes, though possible, are less frequent.

question: Which statement about the gastrointestinal syndrome is true?
a: The threshold dose for induction of the gastrointestinal syndrome is approximately 3 Sv.
b: Patients typically die within a week after exposure to doses in excess of 8 Sv.
c: For acute doses in excess of 10 Sv, hydration and supportive care can reduce the mortality rate.
d: No prodromal symptoms are associated with the gastrointestinal syndrome.
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Shrieve and Loeffler. Human Radiation Injury. Chapter 11. Mettler and Upton. Medical Effects of Ionizing Radiation. 3rd ed. Chapter 6.
rationale: The threshold dose for the full gastrointestinal syndrome is approximately 8-10 Sv, although some of its signs and symptoms are noted after doses of 6 Sv. No human has survived a documented dose of 10 Sv. Patients experience a rapid onset of severe prodromal symptoms within an hour of irradiation, and over the next several days, they develop anorexia, severe nausea, vomiting, cramps, and diarrhea. Patients typically die of septicemia within 10 days of irradiation.

question: Which trial design evaluates how much of a chemotherapy drug should be given and how effective it is at a prescribed dose?
subject: Statistics
rationale: Phase 0: This trial phase is used to gather preliminary data on what a drug does to the human body and what the body does to the drug. Phase I: This trial phase is designed to assess safety, tolerability, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacokinetics. Phase II: This trial phase is designed to assess how much drug should be given as well as has how it works at a prescribed dose. Phase III: During this phase, the drug or treatment is given to large groups of people to confirm its effectiveness, monitor side effects, compare it to commonly used treatments, and collect information that will allow the drug or treatment to be used safely.

question: Which histologic subtype is most common in patients with mesothelioma?
subject: Thorax
rationale: There are three main histologic subtypes of mesothelioma: epithelioid, biphasic, and sarcomatoid. Epithelioid tumors are most common and have a better prognosis than biphasic and sarcomatoid tumors.

question: Which exam best delineates the high-risk CTV when performing image-based contouring with IV contrast for Cervix cancer brachytherapy?
a: MRI before and at the time of the implant
b: CT scan before and at the time of the implant
d: CT scan before the implant only
subject: Gyn
citations: Computed tomography versus magnetic resonance imaging based contouring in Cervix cancer brachytherapy: results of a prospective trial and preliminary guidelines for standardized contours. Int J Radiation Oncology Biol Phys. 2007;68(2):491-498.
rationale: CT, unlike MRI, does not permit a distinction between the corpus and the cervix. Intravenous (IV) contrast does not enhance the tumor on CT; therefore, a GTV recommended by the GEC-ESTRO guidelines for MRI cannot be visualized on CT. CT with IV contrast can delineate the cervicouterine junction at the intersection of the uterine vessels and the cervix which allows demarcation of the upper border of the cervix. This can be used as a guide for contouring of the superior border of the HR-CTV. However, only MRI immediately before and at the time of brachytherapy can accurately delineate the superior border of the HR-CTV for patients with tumor extension beyond the cervix. If MRI is unavailable, the initial tumor extension into the corpus, or at least the entire canal, must be contoured to ensure that the CTV covers the entire extent of potential areas at risk. Accurate delineation of the HR-CTV and IR-CTV requires documentation of the gynecological examination with drawings at diagnosis and at the time of brachytherapy.

question: Which of the following is a high-risk feature for patients with B-precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)?
subject: Lymphoma
rationale: Age older than 10 years, male sex, WBC count greater than 50,000 cells/L, T cell lineage, Ph chromosome positive, CSF positivity, and a slow response are considered to be high-risk features.

question: What is the best treatment approach for a 60-year-old woman who presents with a poorly differentiated stage T1N0 adenocarcinoma of the upper rectum, measuring 2 cm, involving 25% of the circumference with evidence of lymphovascular invasion?
subject: GI
citations: Willett CG, et al. Cancer. 1994;73(11):2716-2720. Willett CG, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology (J Clin Oncol). 1989; 7(8):1003-1008.
rationale: In general, the best candidates for wide local excision (WLE) include small (<4 cm), low-lying tumors confined to the muscularis propria. WLE is not recommended for patients with adverse pathologic features (signet ring histology, poor differentiation, lymphovascular space invasion) or whose tumors occupy >40% of the rectum, which are associated with a high risk for local recurrence. Patients with tumors invading through the muscularis propria (T3) are at very high risk (>30%) for local recurrence following WLE, and therefore, they should not be treated with WLE. Due to the location of the lesion in the mid-to-upper rectum, a low anterior resection for sphincter preservation can be performed.

question: What is the lifetime breast cancer risk for the following populations?
a: Equal risk for women who are carriers of both BRCA1 and BRCA2
b: Equal risk for men who are carriers of both BRCA1 and BRCA2
c: Higher risk for women who are carriers of BRCA1 versus BRCA2
d: Higher risk for men who are carriers of BRCA1 versus BRCA2
subject: Breast
citations: Harris JR, ed. Epidemiology: assessing and managing risk. Diseases of the Breast. 4th ed. 2010, p.214.
rationale: The risk for women is 60% to 80% for carriers of both BRCA1 and BRCA2. The risk for men who are carriers of BRCA1 is 1% to 5%. The risk for men who are carriers of BRCA2 is 5% to 10%.

question: What is the best reason for removing a flattening filter inside a linear accelerator head for certain delivery modes?
a: Electron beams are already flat without the flattening filter.
b: Photon beams are harder without the flattening filter.
c: The dose rate is higher without the flattening filter.
d: The beam profile would result in a more homogeneous dose distribution.
subject: Physics
rationale: The reason to remove the flattening filter is to obtain high-dose-rate beams, and thus, shorter delivery times especially for the treatment of SBRT and SRS cases. Option A is incorrect because the flattening filter is not applicable to electron beams. Option B is incorrect because flattening filters harden photon beams. Option D is incorrect because the beam would be more heterogeneous.

question: Which statement about survival curves for normal cells compared to tumor cells is true?
a: The average D0 for aerobic survival curves of both normal and tumor cells in vitro is in the range of 1 to 2 Gy.
b: There is a systematic difference between the survival curve shapes of normal versus tumor cells.
c: Cells from a given normal tissue show a wide range of radiosensitivities in different individuals.
d: Cells from a given type of tumor show a narrow range of radiosensitivities in different individuals.
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: Survival curve shapes for normal versus tumor cells are not systematically different. Cells from a given normal tissue show a relatively narrow range of radiosensitivities when compared across multiple (genetically wild-type) individuals; however, cells from a given tumor type can show a wide range of radiosensitivities across multiple individuals. The latter is likely a manifestation of the genomic instability of tumor cells and the resulting "evolution" the tumor as a whole undergoes in response to various selective pressures.

question: Which laboratory test is most appropriate in the initial diagnostic workup of patients with suspected multiple myeloma?
subject: Lymphoma
rationale: According to the 2011 NCCN guidelines, 2-microglobulin is most appropriate in the workup for multiple myeloma. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is used for Hodgkin lymphoma; -fetoprotein (AFP) and -human chorionic gonadotropin (-hCG) are used for seminoma.

question: A patient who has stage IIB seminoma with a 4 cm para-aortic lymph node undergoes radical orchiectomy and chemotherapy. A follow-up CT scan demonstrates a 3 cm residual lymph node. What is the most appropriate next step?
subject: GU
rationale: In the case of a post-treatment residual mass, NCCN guidelines indicate that a PET scan should be given 6 weeks after chemotherapy. PET scans in this setting have been shown to have a high positive (100%) and negative predictive value (96%). De Santis, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology (JCO). 2004;22:1034-9.

question: According to the AAPM TG-51 report, reference dosimetry for treatment machines is calibrated in water using which dosimeter?
subject: Physics
rationale: Only ion chambers have a calibration traceable to an Accredited Dosimetry Calibration Laboratory and can be used to calibrate the output of treatment machines.

question: What is the risk that a patient will have a mucosal recurrence after neck dissection alone for an unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to a jugulodigastric lymph node?
subject: H&N
citations: Coster, et al. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 1992;23:743-749.
rationale: The reason patients are treated in the setting of an unknown primary is the extent of disease in the neck and not the primary. The risk of a mucosal recurrence is only 25% for patients with stage N1 disease treated with surgery alone.

question: Which syndrome is most commonly associated with a pineal lesion?
subject: CNS
rationale: Parinaud's syndrome is associated with 1) paralysis of upgaze, 2) pseudo-Argyll Robertson pupils in which accommodative paresis ensues, the pupils become mid-dilated and show light-near dissociation, 3) convergence-retraction nystagmus, 4) eyelid retraction (Collier's sign), and 5) conjugate downgaze in the primary position.

question: What mortality outcome would be expected if nine individuals were exposed to an acute, whole-body radiation dose of 3.5 Sv?
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Shrieve and Loeffler. Human Radiation Injury. Chapter 10.
rationale: The hematopoietic or bone marrow syndrome is caused by an acute, whole-body radiation dose of approximately 2 Sv or higher. In the absence of medical intervention (i.e., bone marrow transplant), the human LD50/60 is 3-4 Sv. Death from whole-body radiation exposure on a time scale of days to a little more than a week is more consistent with either the cerebrovascular (1-2 days) or gastrointestinal (7-10 days) syndromes, and both of these syndromes have threshold doses significantly higher than 3.5 Sv.

question: Which type of study evaluates two groups of patients with prostate cancer previously treated with the same dose of radiation (one group with rectal bleeding, one group without rectal bleeding) to determine if IMRT can reduce rectal toxicity in comparison to 3D conformal therapy?
subject: GU
citations: Dawson B and Trapp RG. Basic and Clinical Biostatistics. 4th ed. 2004. pp 333 and 404.
rationale: A case-control study is an observational study that begins with patients who have the outcome (rectal toxicity in this case) or disease being investigated and control subjects who do not have the outcome or disease. It then looks backward to identify possible precursors or risk factors.

question: Which outcome was demonstrated by the Intergroup 0139 trial comparing chemoradiation to chemoradiation followed by resection (trimodality) for patients with stage IIIA NSCLC?
a: No overall survival benefit due to increased mortality rates from lobectomy
b: No overall survival benefit due to increased mortality from left-sided pneumonectomies
c: Improved overall survival only after right-sided pneumonectomies
d: Improved progression-free survival, but not overall survival
subject: Thorax
citations: Albain KS, et al. Lancet. 2009.
rationale: In the Intergroup 0139 trial, overall survival (OS) was compromised because of increased mortality from right-sided pneumonectomies (14 deaths from pneumonectomies, 11 of which were right sided). Therefore, progression free survival (PFS) improved but not OS. However, a subset analysis of patients with lobectomy showed an improved OS with trimodality therapy.

question: According to the American Brachytherapy Society guidelines for Cervix cancer, what is the recommended dose rate (Gy/hr) to the periphery of an LDR interstitial implant?
subject: Physics
citations: The American Brachytherapy Society (ABS) recommendations for low-dose-rate brachytherapy for carcinoma of the cervix. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics (Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys). 2002;52(1):33-48.
rationale: A dose rate of 0.50 to 0.70 Gy/hr to the periphery of the implant is recommended for interstitial implants. Use of differential source activity or loading minimizes excessive central dose rates.

question: Which radiation dose would be most appropriate to administer to the testes of patients with persistent testicular acute lymphoblastic leukemia after completion of induction therapy?
subject: Lymphoma
rationale: The standard dose for patients with high-risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia, testicular leukemia at diagnosis, and continued evidence of testicular leukemia at the end of induction therapy is 24 Gy and should be administered during consolidation. As specified in COG protocols, including: Children's Oncology Group AALL08P1 Intensified PEG-Asparaginase in High Risk Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL): A Pilot Study.

question: PLD is repaired when survival is higher in:
a: density-inhibited cells that are subcultured 12 hours after irradiation compared to those plated immediately after irradiation.
b: density-inhibited cells that are subcultured immediately after irradiation compared to those plated 12 hours later.
c: rapidly dividing cells that are irradiated using two equal dose fractions separated by 12 hours than those receiving the total dose in one large fraction.
d: rapidly dividing cells that are subcultured 12 hours after irradiation compared to those plated immediately after irradiation.
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Hall and Giaccia. Radbio for the Radiologist. 6th ed. Chapter 5.
rationale: Potentially lethal damage (PLD) is said to be repaired when the subculture of non-cycling, density-inhibited cells is delayed, and the delay results in increased cell survival for what is otherwise the same radiation dose. Repair that is manifest as increased cell survival between fractionated doses is termed sublethal damage (SLD) repair.

question: According to the NCCN Guidelines, staging for stage II breast cancer does NOT include which of the following tests?
subject: Breast
citations: Puglisi F, et al. Baseline staging tests after new diagnosis of breast cancer: further evidence of their limited indications. Ann Oncol. 2005; 16:263-266.
rationale: Per NCCN Guidelines, staging studies for patients with stage I, II, or T3N1M0 disease should include a bone scan, CT imaging of the abdomen, ultrasound or MRI and chest imaging, but they are only indicated when patients have symptoms, signs, or findings related to the bone, abdomen, or chest (such as pain, abnormal liver function tests, pulmonary symptoms, etc.). According to Puglisi, et al., chest x-rays (CXR) detected lung metastases in 0.72% of patients. Bone scans were positive for stage I disease in 5.1% of patients, for stage II in 5.6% of patients, and for stage III in 14% of patients. There were no patients with liver metastases identified by ultrasound and no lesions identified by chest x-ray in the study. Recommendations were for limited baseline staging tests, especially liver ultrasound and CXR, to patients at higher risk (stage III) of distant metastases.

question: According to the AAPM TG-34 report, what is the maximum recommended total dose to a permanently implanted cardiac pacemaker?
subject: Physics
rationale: The AAPM Task Group 34 (AAPM TG-34) report recommends limiting the accumulated dose to a permanent pacemaker to 2 Gy. Since the time of this report, there have been considerable changes made to the circuitry of pacemakers. In addition, at the time of the report, implanted cardiac defibrillators (ICDs) were just beginning to emerge, and as such, the report did not provide dose recommendations for ICDs. At present, a new AAPM Task Group (203) has been convened to review and revise these recommendations.

question: Which statement about human tumor xenografts transplanted into small animals is true?
a: Xenografts are transplanted into immune-competent mice.
b: Human tumor cells do not undergo cell cycle kinetic changes when transplanted.
c: The murine vasculature does not affect drug pharmacokinetics in the xenografts.
d: The histological characteristics of the human tumor are maintained after xenografting.
subject: Radiobiology
rationale: The goal of a good tumor model system is to mimic as closely as possible the conditions that occur in human tumors in situ. Human tumors maintain their histopathological characteristics after xenografting. However, the fact that an immune-compromised animal must be used, that tumor cells undergo kinetic changes when transplanted, and that the vascular supply from the host can complicate the interpretation of, for example, drug pharmacokinetic experiments, are all factors that must be taken into account when analyzing the results of experiments using human tumor xenografts.

question: According to the NCCN Guidelines, PET scans are recommended for soft tissue sarcomas of the extremity to:
a: confirm the radiation field design for postoperative therapy.
b: assess the tumor response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
c: assess for residual primary tumors postoperatively.
d: provide follow-up surveillance after primary therapy.
subject: Sarcoma
citations: Schuetze, SM. Utility of positron emission tomography in sarcomas. Current Opinion in Oncology. 2006;18:369-373.
rationale: PET scans may be useful for prognostication, grading, and assessment of tumor response to chemotherapy.

question: Which criterion is associated with stage III multiple myeloma?
subject: Lymphoma
rationale: According to the Durie-Salmon Criteria, a criterion for stage III multiple myeloma is a serum calcium level of >12 mg/dL. NCCN Guidelines, 2011.

question: What is the risk of recurrence in the para-aortic lymph nodes after orchiectomy for a stage I pure seminoma?
subject: GU
rationale: Approximately 15% to 20% of patients who have stage I pure seminoma and undergo active surveillance will have recurrence in the para-aortic lymphatics after initial orchiectomy.

question: Which value is commonly used to differentiate a megavoltage photon energy from other energies?
subject: Physics
rationale: All of these can be used to describe beam energy, but only the tissue maximum ratio (TMR) is used for megavoltage photon beams. Practical range and R50, the depth of 50% of the dose relative to dmax, are used for electron beams. Half value layer (HVL) is used for orthovoltage beams.

question: Combined cetuximab with postoperative radiation for oral cavity cancer is:
a: the standard of care for patients with positive margins or extracapsular extension.
b: the standard of care for patients with multiple positive lymph nodes.
c: superior to cisplatin due its reduced toxic effect.
subject: H&N
rationale: The use of cetuximab in the postoperative setting is currently being investigated in RTOG protocol 0920.

question: A 19-year-old patient has a 2 cm pineal mass noted on MRI. CSF cytology and serum -hCG and AFP levels are negative. What is the most appropriate next management step?
subject: Pediatrics
rationale: Pineal masses without elevation of blood or serum markers should have pathologic confirmation of diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes pineal parenchymal tumors, germ cell tumors, glioma, and meningioma. Each would require a less different management approach.

question: Radiation-induced heart disease is primarily due to:
a: chronic irritation and proliferation of the serous pericardium, causing pericarditis.
b: proinflammatory cytokine signaling that enhances arteriosclerosis and microvascular dysfunction.
c: late loss of vascular endothelial cells, leading to myocardial infarction.
d: late fibrosis of the myocardium, causing congestive heart failure.
subject: Radiobiology
citations: Shrieve and Loeffler. Human Radiation Injury. Chapter 29.
rationale: Irradiation of cardiac vascular endothelial cells has been proposed to stimulate proinflammatory signals, which enhance arteriosclerosis and microvascular dysfunction. Radiation pericarditis is no longer a common complication of radiation therapy, as large-volume irradiation is now discouraged. Also, the pericardial reaction is related to irritation of the fibrous, not necessarily the serous pericardium. Myocardial fibrosis and endothelial cell loss are not known to have any significant contributions to radiation-induced heart disease.

question: Approximately what proportion of patients with SCLC present with limited-stage disease?
subject: Thorax
citations: Govindan R, et al. Journal of Clinical Oncology. Vol 24, No 28 (October 1), 2006: pp 4539-4544.
rationale: The majority of patients with small cell lung cancer (SCLC) are more likely to present with extensive-stage disease. The latest epidemiological study showed 39.6% of patients were staged as limited stage, 56.6% were extensive stage, and 3.8% were unstaged.

question: According to NCCN Cervix cancer guidelines, what is the most appropriate treatment for positive para-aortic lymph nodes found during surgical staging with a negative postoperative PET-CT scan?
d: Cisplatin with pelvic and para-aortic irradiation
subject: Gyn
